SHACL.Definition: SHACL (Shapes Constraint Language) is a language used to validate RDF data against predefined shapes.
SHACL.Purpose: It ensures data integrity, compliance with standards, and facilitates machine understanding.

Constraint_Types.Value_Constraints: Check if values meet specific conditions such as being within a range.
Constraint_Types.Relational_Constraints: Define relationships between nodes ensuring structural correctness.
Constraint_Types.Mathematical_Constraints: Use mathematical expressions to define constraints on values.
Constraint_Types.Logical_Constraints: Incorporate logical operators to combine multiple constraints.

Usage.Data_Validation: SHACL is widely used to validate RDF data, ensuring it adheres to models and ontologies.
Usage.Application_In_Industries: Used in healthcare, finance, and building information modeling for ensuring data conforms to standards.

NodeShapes_and_PropertyShapes.NodeShapes: Define constraints applicable to RDF nodes. They specify required properties and/or that values of these properties meet certain conditions.
NodeShapes_and_PropertyShapes.PropertyShapes: Part of NodeShapes, defining constraints for specific properties within a NodeShape. They impose requirements on the property's value, such as minimum or maximum values.

Targeting.Description: sh:targetClass is used to indicate the class of nodes to which the shape applies, imposing constraints on all instances of this class.

Paths_and_Values.Description: sh:path specifies the path to the property in the RDF data structure that the shape targets.
Paths_and_Values.Constraints: Properties like sh:minInclusive and sh:maxInclusive set numerical limits on property values.
